results.description:
For coworking space, it's first come first served. You'll want to get there early to find a desk before it fills up. The space is available from 10am to 6pm. If you are planning on attending, you'll need to do the following things:

• Register at the AWS Pop-up Loft Space - https://aws.amazon.com/start-ups/loft/ny-loft/

• Once you are registered you can pick up a badge and attend any of the co-working meetups.

• Let us know you are going by signing up for the event on meetup. This also lets other people in the group know who is going to be there too.

• Remember to check the Pop-up Loft website to make sure it is open. We'll do out best to cancel meetups on holidays and days the space won't be available but you should also double check before coming out.

• While there are snacks and drinks at the space, lunch is not provided. There are a number of restaurants, delis and other places to get food in the area so plan accordingly

• These daily coworking events are self run. A co-organizer will not always be at the event. These events are designed to give game developers a free space to work so you'll basically be left alone at the space to do you own thing. We suggest reaching out to other attending through the comments to sit together or meet up at a specific time in the space.

Last thing, two times a month we'll have a dedicated space for you to come out and work as well as listen to talks and get help from myself and others in the community. Those will be different events you'll need to register for which are separate from the daily co-working space.
results.name: Indie Coworking Space

results.description:
A mix is a great way to showcase your talent, the tracks that get you bumping and the tracks that have inspired you on the path of DJ-ing. So think of the bedroom as your house of worship. Honor it, pay reverence to it and give us a damn good mix worthy of the pantheon of the DJ gods on Mt. Olympus.

Some common ground rules to ensure a quality mix and ensure serious commitment:

•  House, deep-house, tech-house, techno, minimal, EDM or any other genre that fits into the house category.

• High quality mp3/wav 320kbps.

• Record a 1 hour mix without peaks, in other words; no clipping!

• Transitions need to be well segued, near flawless

• Sample mix required to ensure DJ commitment and whether or not you make the cut for the radio show

• A great profile pic

So once you’ve ticked all these off the list, you’re on your way to getting your DJ mix broadcasted. We’re especially reaching out to our new and beginning DJ's looking to make their mark. Send us a link where we can download your mix. Send us a profile picture too, so we can add it to the visual in case your mix has been selected for the weekly broadcast on Saturday (soundboxonline.com). Also check out Carl J and ADG presents where you can find all of our mixes back. Looking forward to hearing some great mixes.

Ayelmer Veenstra --- LMR

A.D.G.

~ pls. send the visual and the link to (download) your mix to: [masked]

results.description:
It's probably not a surprise that the #1 barrier to the adoption of Agile is  change?  Shifting organizational culture, which Agile requires does not happen overnight. Driving true cultural change needs commitment and nurturing from all levels of an organization.  In this one hour event, hear from Pinar Ayorak on how to create a culture that fosters adoption and acceptance of change towards Agile methodology.

Pınar has over 15 years in the technology industry, with the last 8 years being spent in Agile environments and currently with OBSS. She has helped lead companies in their Agile implementations by coaching dozens of Agile project teams and training individuals on Agile Methodology. Prior to Agile, from software developer through software architect and project manager, she has worked on every software tier from embedded to enterprise systems in diverse industries.Her experience includes teams distributed in USA, Holland, India, England and Turkey.It is this extensive experience that defines her position in OBSS as project office leadership, program and project management and process improvement.  Pınar received her Bachelor of Science Degree in Computer Science with minor in Business Administration from Northeastern University in Boston, USA.She is a member of Scrum Alliance.
results.name: Organizational Impact of Agile: Lunch & Learn

results.description:
We will do cold readings of plays in progress and short pieces from 1 to 2pm and then from 2 to 3pm -- if you are an actor pressed for time that day, please let me know if 1pm or 2pm works better for you, and I will try to accommodate your needs! I want you to be able to participate with ease. 

At 3pm, we write til 4pm with a prompt. If you are only coming to write, please come by 3pm so we can start on time without interruptions. If you have paid in advance for the workshop, and you can't attend a writing session, the prompt will be sent to your email, so make sure I have your email. If you have a piece to be read, please try to send it to me via email in advance with a character breakdown to help me with casting. 

You are also free to cast your own piece -- you may not cast yourself in your piece. Give yourself the chance to honor your writing by listening to it as a writer. You may know exactly how you want it done, but that doesn't necessarily help you as a writer. Trust me on this, or ask me about it -- I am happy to discuss it with you. You can also bring in a piece and ask to have it read, and we'll read it cold. 

Please check your piece for time! Each writer gets up to ten minutes of material. This usually means ten pages if you write in accepted format with 12 point Courier font and your pages are not full of monologues. Monologues read longer than a minute a page. So time your work. 

Write Now Workshop is free for actors, but writers pay a fee that I am trying to reduce by 1) opening the workshop up to the community for free as a model for creating community and involvement and offering content to seniors who live nearby and 2) using a space that doesn't cost me a fortune (most of the fees are space fees) and 3) applying for funding as we grow and documenting the way the concept works and 4) having the workshop subsidized by patrons of the arts (already happening so that I can offer it at the current rate). 

The writers fees are currently $35 per session or $30 in advance for 9 workshops at $270 payable by cash or check or paypal to [masked]


Thank you! 

Write Now; Right Later!
Emma
results.name: Read Plays, Respond, and Write!

results.description:
For Registration Link click here!

Richard D. Wyckoff, one of the founding titans of technical analysis, developed a method in the early 20th century to anticipate future market direction by analyzing only price, volume and time. Many successful professional and institutional traders still rely on his principles of judging the market by its own action; Wyckoffs approach is as valid today as when it was first articulated and continues to work well for any freely traded security in any time frame.

In this presentation, Mr. Roman Bogomazov, an internationally recognized expert in the Wyckoff Method, will describe how to apply this approach for several different instruments in multiple time frames. He will demonstrate how Wyckoff-style analysis identifies high-probability opportunities in stocks, e-minis, and forex even in the volatile markets of the past year. The Wyckoff Method provides reliable signals regardless of a traders time horizon, as Mr. Bogomazov will illustrate with case studies using intra-day, daily and longer-term charts. Traders of all levels of skill and experience will definitely benefit from this presentation.
results.name: Applying the Wyckoff Method in Any Time Frame

Emotions, Emotions, Emotions is an interactive music concert focusing on emotions. We will explore various feelings with original songs, humor, fun movement activities and music technology. This show is accessible for all children including children and teens on the autism spectrum. Some of the emotions we will explore in the show include happy, sad, angry, scared, sick and many other important emotions that children need to express themselves. Best for ages 2 years and older.

I will bring along my bag full of prompts if anyone wants to peruse them to get started, but, for all intents and purposes, this meetup is an opportunity to support you in whatever you need to be working on now.

We have changed the location of the weekly write-ins to the Barnes & Noble cafe.  Since there has been such a low turn out for our write-ins, we figured we should be able to meet in the cafe without causing too much trouble there. results.description:
Modern Monetary Circuit Theory

Alexander Lipton

Seminar Program

5:45pm Registration
6:00pm Seminar
7:30pm Reception

Abstract

A modern version of Monetary Circuit Theory with a particular emphasis on stochastic underpinning mechanisms is developed. It is explained how money is created by the banking system as a whole and by individual banks. The role of central banks as system stabilizers and liquidity providers is elucidated. Both the Chicago Plan and the Free Banking Proposal are discussed. It is shown how in the process of money creation, banks become naturally interconnected. A novel Extended Structural Default Model describing the stability of the Interconnected Banking Network is proposed. The purpose of bank capital and liquidity is explained. A multi-period constrained optimization problem for a bank’s balance sheet is formulated and solved in a simple case. Both theoretical and practical aspects are covered.


Biography

Alexander Lipton is a Managing Director, Quantitative Solutions Executive at Bank of America, Visiting Professor of Quantitative Finance at University of Oxford and Advisory Board member at the Oxford-Man Institute.

Prior to his current role, he was a Managing Director, Co-head of the Global Quantitative Group at Bank of America Merrill Lynch and a Visiting Professor of Mathematics at Imperial College London. Earlier, he was a Managing Director and Head of Capital Structure Quantitative Research at Citadel Investment Group in Chicago; he has also worked for Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank and Bankers Trust. Before switching to finance, Alex was a Full Professor of Mathematics at the University of Illinois and a Consultant at Los Alamos National Laboratory. He received his undergraduate and graduate degrees in pure mathematics from Moscow State University.

Lipton’s interests encompass all aspects of financial engineering, including large-scale bank balance sheet modeling and optimization, enterprise-wide holistic risk management and stress testing, CCPs, electronic trading, trading strategies, payment systems, theory of monetary circuit, as well as hydrodynamics, magnetohydrodynamics, and astrophysics. Lipton authored two books, and edited five books, including, most recently, Risk Quant of the Year Award, Risk Books, London, 2014, and The Oxford Handbook of Credit Derivatives, Oxford University Press, Oxford, 2011 (with Andrew Rennie). He published more than a hundred scientific papers on a variety of topics in applied mathematics and financial engineering.


Disclaimer

This a joint IAQF/Thalesians seminar, and not an instructional program of New York University.
results.name: (NY) - Alexander Lipton - Modern Monetary Circuit Theory

results.description:
This event is currently at its maximum and is closed to new players.

From humble beginnings, a handful of lost souls must rise above their misfortune to achieve greatness.

The uncountable islands of the subtropical Korina Archipelago are the sanctuary for many who have fled from the never-ending wars of distant Altamere. That land, where the life of the common man is cheap and reckless kings all-too-often burn their lives, and kingdoms, out in blazes of glory.

The Korina Archipelago is home to several large city-states, each of which views the others as rivals, but generally coexist, for there are greater threats to their safety. Renegade Altameran privateers, depraved nation-less pirates, demon-worshiping cannibals, horrors from the uncharted oceans, and far worse are reminders for the city-states of the constant dangers that exist outside their walls. 

These dangers are all-too-real, and to whom can one turn to in times of desperation and need when threats arise? Each city-state will defend its own, but outside that, help is not easy to come by. Even the enlightened gods favor all, yet they favor none; those whose prayers and sacrifices are the most persuasive bend their ears for a time. The gods are powerful and wise, but fickle they are, too, and to understand their ways is not the way of man.

This is no place for the weak of heart. Salvation comes from strength and strength alone. The strong survive, the weak do not. This is the tale of the rising of heroes, the elevation of men from what they were to what they are, the making of the great from the small, this is the story of ascension.
results.name: Ascension: The Isle of Dread

results.description:
** This game is currently closed to new players.  We have a full house.**

Part I: Servants of the Elder Eye

Following the fall of the Temple of Elemental Evil, peace was restored to the lands of Central Flanaess... for a time. Now, in the wake of the kidnapping of Prince Thrommel of Furyondy, rumors abound of cultists making their way back into the blighted lands surrounding the ruins of The Temple. With these rumors comes a growing sense of paranoia among the people of nearby settlements, and mysterious disappearances and deaths threaten to throw the lands back into chaos.

This 5th Edition D&D game is great for new or experienced players, and will take characters from level 1 to level 10.

The game will be hosted at Barnes & Noble in Edison NJ.  Sessions should run from 6pm until 9:45pm.


Additional resources: 


Guide to Greyhawk - This pdf gives a brief overview of the campaign world, including new subraces and an expanded list of gods and their domains. 

World of Greyhawk - My website for this classic campaign setting. 


Greyhawk Game - My site for the game, once it starts.

Character Generation Guidelines - This explains some of the basics of character creation for the game.
results.name: The World of Greyhawk - Servants of the Elder Eye

results.description:
About the talk:

We're excited to announce a night with Dr. Jeff Sutherland, the co-creator of Scrum and CEO of Scrum Inc. The talk is held in collaboration with another meetup group "Scaling Agile NYC" and will be held at the Kaplan Test Prep offices and is sponsored by BEC.

Jeff will share, from his experience working with teams around the globe, what it takes to deliver working software faster, easier and smarter. 

Agenda:

• 6:00 PM Grab a slice of pizza & a drink
• 6:10 PM Announcements
• 6:15 PM Program starts followed by Q&A
• 8:00 PM End 

About the speaker: 

Dr. Jeff Sutherland is the co-creator of Scrum and a leading expert on how the framework has evolved to meet the needs of today’s business. The framework he developed in 1993 and formalized in 1995 with Ken Schwaber has since been adopted by the vast majority of software development companies around the world. But Jeff realized that the benefits of Scrum are not limited to software and product development. He has adapted this successful strategy for several other industries including: finance, healthcare, higher education and telecom.
results.name: Jeff Sutherland in NYC!

results.description:
Web Development in Angular 2 with TypeScript

Angular 2 is a complete re-write of AngularJS, which according to the Pluralsight survey leads the list of what developers want to learn in 2016. Angular 2 is a component-based framework that has no controllers and scopes. It has simplified DI and is easier to learn than AngularJS, but the tooling is a little more complex. This presentation is an overview of the Angular 2 framework. All code samples are provided in TypeScript, which is a recommended language for developing Angular 2 applications. We’ll also go over the tools required to develop and deploy Angular 2 applications. 

Yakov Fain is Java Champion and a co-founder of the IT consultancy Farata Systems. He wrote a thousand blogs and several books about software development. He's a co-author of the upcoming Manning book "Angular 2 Development with TypeScript". Most of all Yakov enjoys learning and teaching software. 


Agenda:

6:00pm - Doors open, Food, Drinks and Socializing

6:20pm - Talk from Yakov Fain

(any remaining time) - Lightning Demos 

8:00pm - The end
results.how_to_find_us: Enter Chelsea Market using the 9th Ave entrance. You will see a security guard on the right. Take the stairs to the second floor and you will find the Google lobby.
results.name: AngularJS Meetup March 2016: Web Development in Angular 2 with TypeScript

The evidence is overwhelming that more diverse sales teams lead to better financial performance and higher revenues per sales rep.  The question then becomes how to find, attract, and keep women and minority sales talent in order to reap the benefits. 

Join us for this panel with three inspiring leaders who will share their personal experiences as a women and as minorities in the enterprise sales profession, how they became leaders, and their views on creating high performing B2B sales teams through a diverse talent pool.

Joining us on our panel of sales leaders, we will have:

• Kristin Shevis, SVP Sales and Services at Conversocial

• Safiyyah Saafir, Principal at Saleosophy

• Eric Maldonado, Managing Director of Sales at Markit

We look forward to hearing more about their journey in sales and candid experiences in reaching success in their careers as sales professionals and leaders.

We encourage you to share our community and this event with your colleagues and friends in sales.  You can https://www.universe.com/salesdiversity">post on LinkedIn and share over Twitter as well as following the conversation on our group hashtag #B2BSales.
results.name: Building High Performing & Diverse Sales Teams

results.description:
Just read about the release of this memoir in the paper this morning, and super excited to give it a read! Here's the description:

In a fit of idealism, Ed Boland left a twenty-year career as a non-profit executive to teach in a tough New York City public high school. But his hopes quickly collided headlong with the appalling reality of his students' lives and a hobbled education system unable to help them: Freddy runs a drug ring for his incarcerated brother; Nee-cole is homeschooled on the subway by her brilliant homeless mother; and Byron's Ivy League dream is dashed because he is undocumented.

In the end, Boland isn't hoisted on his students' shoulders and no one passes AP anything. This is no urban fairy tale of at-risk kids saved by a Hollywood hero, but a searing indictment of schools that claim to be progressive but still fail their students. Told with compassion, humor, and a keen eye, Boland's story is sure to ignite debate about the future of American education and attempts to reform it.

You can get the book here: http://amzn.to/1nzHGxD

p.s. this restaurant has a fire place, so hopefully we can sit near it this time to sip our sangria!;-)
results.name: Discuss "The Battle For Room 314" and eat Nicaraguan food!

Join us for the Open Entrepreneur Pitching Event for Digital Media, High Tech and Healthcare Start-Ups

Every Entrepreneur Gets a Table - We Bring the Investors to You!

Now with more Investors than ever! Every Start-Up gets to pitch to our team of Investors - the audience gets to find out what's new in the Start-Up market, and what VC's are really looking for!

Plus we have added our famous Capital Raising Workshop - use our mastermind group to shape your winning pitch. All our last winners or finalist have graduated from this workshop.

Capital Raising Workshop  3:30 - 5: 30 pm

Startup Pitching 6:00 - 9:00 pm

After more than 10 years of helping selected Entrepreneurs raise capital - we've figured how to open it up to everyone!

This innovative event gives every Entrepreneur a shot at getting the attention of Angel Investors on the lookout for new deals. Tech & Digital Media VCs and execs get a unique opportunity to survey the marketplace at their own pace.

Startupalooza is a unique pitching contest where all start ups are ranked by a large group on Investors. The Top 4 get to do a public "pitch-off" and the winner gets up to $4500 in prizes.

Dear Startup Members, 

By popular demand, we have added our Capital Raising Workshop to the October 20th event. It rums from 3:30 - 5: 30 and itis Free if you sign up for Startupalooza

results.description:
Join us at Metis in New York City on Tuesday, March 15th at 6:00pm to hear a talk from Ruben Naeff, Data Scientist at Knewton (an adaptive education startup). 

Ruben joins us as part of our ongoing speaker series, which provides Metis Data Science Bootcamp students with exposure to leaders in data science who are working in a wide variety of industries. Ruben's talk is open to the public, with limited seating available. 

The Topic: Predicting Student Responses

The rapid growth of web-based educational products has garnered renewed interest into methods that infer student proficiency and question difficulty. One central question is how well we can predict student responses. In this talk, Ruben Naeff discusses such traditional methods as Classical Test Theory (CTT) and Item Response Theory and compares the result of Bayesian optimization with a graph-theoretical algorithm based on tournament ranking that approximates an upper bound to both traditional models’ single interaction prediction accuracy. 

Check out a related blog post and Ruben's NIPS paper for more information. 

Ruben Naeff
Data Scientist, Knewton

Ruben is from Amsterdam, the Netherlands, where he studied mathematics and worked as a strategy consultant and economic researcher. Currently, he works as a Data Scientist at Knewton, an adaptive education startup in New York City, and has worked as data science instructor for General Assembly. Aside from his data science career, Ruben is a composer with a degree from NYU. His music has been performed throughout Europe, Asia, and the United States.

Visit his website at: rubennaeff.nl
results.name: Predicting Student Responses with Ruben Naeff, Data Scientist at Knewton

results.description:
Tuesday is Arduino night at Fat Cat Fab Lab!

We have lots more Arduinos, breadboards, and parts, so bring your laptop and come join us for a fun hands-on learning experience.

Schedule: 


IMPORTANT: Our meetups are all about hands-on learning, so please remember to bring your laptop.


6:00-6:15  Introduction - general questions answered.

6:15-6:45 A brief introduction to ArduBlock, a very friendly visual language for programming Arduino that is used to teach Arduino in grade school.  If you know about Scratch, the ArduBlock interface is a lot like Scratch.  


6:45-8:30 Hands on workshop If you are new to Arduino, we'll help you hook one up to your laptop and start experimenting.  Otherwise you are free to work on your own project, experiment with senors, or help someone else with their project.


--------------------------------------------------------------

Stewart Newfeld, our Arduino Tuesdays host has a an Electrical Engineering degree from Rutgers University, years of industry experience, and loves to teach and share his enthusiasm for making things. He enjoys ordering those so-inexpensive electronic parts from ebay and Aliexpress and having them show up like little toys two to three weeks later in his mailbox. He is president of Zebra Systems, Inc. where he develops websites with the Joomla Open Source CMS.

--------------------------------------------------------------

It's been been a while, but the NJ LGBT Chamber of Commerce is back at our Montclair favorite, Pig and Prince, a superstar on the eclectic Montclair dining scene.

All reviews rave about this restaurant's stunningly restored, turn of the 20th century interior.  

From New Jersey Monthly Magazine: "Smashingly set in the restored waiting room of Montclair’s century-old Lackawanna railroad station, Pig & Prince oozes architectural character." 

It may be the winter, but that doesn't mean you have to sit on the couch and watch reality TV.  Come out, meet your peers and make new connections.  

The Chamber's board of directors will be there to facilitate introductions and happily discuss the benefits of becoming a chamber member and applying for LGBT business owner certification.  

We'll have our private party in the Tap Room, where you'll enjoy Happy Hour pricing on wines and craft beers, as well as enjoy signature LGBT Chamber cocktails, created just for us... 

Bring your business cards to pass around and remember to give one to a Chamber Director -- we'll be raffling off a free one-year membership! 

                            IT PAYS TO BE A MEMBER OF THE CHAMBER!

results.description:
You're invited to hack along with the New York Linux Users Group!


Please have a government issued form of ID with you.


This is a peer-supported workshop where we get together to share current challenges and approaches to solving problems or to just work alongside like-minded individuals and learn through osmosis.

This event is NOT a lecture-style meeting. The agenda is generally set when someone poses a question, so bring questions!

Some topics up for discussion are:

• Install and configuration assistance

• Documentation, standards, and best practices

• Current events/Conventions

• Release testing and bug reporting

• Getting started with languages like Python and LaTeX

• -Other projects (Pi/Arduino/Analog devices)

We will also have brief (approx. 5-10 minute) lightning talks, so please speak with a coordinator if you're interested in sharing some of your work.

A laptop is not required but strongly recommended.

Bring a project, topic, and questions and work with other enthusiasts on using Linux or get assistance with your own Linux/Open Source projects. Geeks are more sociable solving problems rather then just talking about themselves.

results.description:
Join us as we welcome back Maggie Kaszuba to our MCA-I New Jersey Chapter!

Many of you know Maggie from her student days at FDU.
A recent graduate and student of our own David Landau's,
Maggie graduated from FDU with a degree in Film and Entertainment Management. 

She is currently working as a Freelance Production Assistant and 2nd AD in the industry.
In addition, she has Assistant Directed two feature films (Stray and Dark Tarot), 4 short films, and is currently shooting a web series. 

What she aspires to be: An AD in the DGA someday. (We have total faith in her!)

Maggie will be coming back to MCA-I NJ to talk to us about her film INSPIRED.
INSPIRED has been an official selection in 14 film festivals and has been nominated and won the following:

-The Shawna Shea Film Festival - Boston, MA (Best Student Short)
-The Brightside Film Festival - Jersey City, NJ (Best Student Short)
The Garden State Film Festival -Atlantic City, NJ 
The American Film Award Festival - Online- (Honorable Mention)
The Kinolit Film Festival - Online - (Nominated for Best Student Short)
He'll talk to us about packaging your script or your feature to present to investors for financing.

Join us as we welcome back an up and coming filmmaker.

Since Maggie is up-and-coming....this might also be a great time to talk about what's happening in your business world and educate each other.

What’s going on with your business, your life, and the world, and how are they interrelating?What have you discovered that is making bad things better?What do you watch out for to keep good things from going south?What’s on your mind that you haven’t been able to talk about with others in our industry?Tech issues?Client issues?Marketing questions?Here’s your opportunity to share your knowledge and experience with your friends and fellow professionals, as MCA-I New Jersey presents an Open Forum at its March meeting,


Bring the topics you’re interested in to the group; you’d be surprised at how much the pooled knowledge of the group can help.


WHEN: Tuesday, March 15th, 2016, 6:30 pm 


WHERE: Fairleigh Dickinson University's Florham Park/Madison Campus, 

Rutherford Room (2nd floor, Rec Center), 

285 Madison Avenue, Madison, NJ 07940


WHO SHOULD ATTEND: Anyone involved in or interested in the filmmaking, moving image, media production industry and its participants.


Please RSVP to Dave Sica at <a>[masked]</a>

DIRECTIONS: www.fdu.edu

and follow directions to the Florham Park campus. 

Important: Be sure to allow extra travel time at rush hour. 

FOOD AND REFRESHMENTS WILL BE SERVED 

Networking and pizza: 6:30 pm-7:00pm;

Chapter business, 7:00pm;

Presentation: 7:15 pm until the fun ends!

Members of any MCA-I chapter: FREE.

Non-members: $10.00.

Students: $5

(Cash or check made out to MCA-I only, please.) 

JOIN US!  See you there!!

results.description:
Henry sold part of the business he co-founded to Microsoft but he lost his best friend along the way and he was not happy.   Join us and learn how to prevent this from happening to you!

Over the course of more than 20 years, Henry has leveraged his entrepreneurial skills, leadership experience and passion for all things IT to lead the development and launch of innovative solutions within competitive markets to prove being the best isn’t about size, it’s about maximizing opportunities to creatively solve problems. Henry’s strategic vision, creative thinking and commitment to customer care has resulted in tremendous value to a wealth of clients around the globe. Henry holds a BS in Computer Science from Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, and enjoys pushing the boundaries to squeeze every drop out of life.

Since its establishment in 1993, Henry Bestritsky has served at the helm of Binary Tree as Co-CEO. After 20 years, Henry sold his stock to Binary Tree. Under Henry's leadership, Binary Tree was able to grow rapidly and make the INC. 5000 multiple times. He was the visionary and creative force behind Binary Tree's growth.


Now Henry has founded a new company called StrataBlue also with a family friend.  Based on the lessons learned Henry and StrataBlue are doing well! Join us and hear Henry's story!

Agenda for the evening is as follows:


6:30 to 7:00 Pizza & Networking


7:00 to 7:10 Updates

7:10 to 7:20 Audience/Member Announcements and Requests

7:20 to 7:30 Startup Pitch #1


7:40 to 7:50 Startup Pitch #2

results.description:
Event space and refreshments sponsored by:  Clarifai

Special Note:  The building doorman leaves at 7pm.  There will be someone downstairs until 7:15 to let latecomers in.  Unfortunately, there will be no entry to the event after 7:15.  

Event agenda:

6:30 - 7:00 PM: Networking & Food  

7:00 - 7:15 PM: Lightning Talks (5 mins each)  

7:15 - 8:30 PM: Keynote talk by Matthew Zeiler

8:30 - 9:00 PM: Socializing


Lightning Talks:

We would like to have three 5-minute talks + 1 minute Q&A. This can simply be an introduction to the group about who you are and what you work on, or you can cover some aspect of Machine Learning or Data Science that you find interesting.  This is open to everyone and we encourage people of all skill levels to give a talk.  It's a great way to introduce yourself to the group!

So grab a spot HERE and tell us more about what you are passionate about and the awesome things you are working on.


About the Talk

Clarifai is an artificial intelligence company that excels in visual recognition and solves real-world problems for businesses and developers alike. Founded in 2013 by Matthew Zeiler, a foremost expert in machine learning, Clarifai has been a market leader since winning the top five places in image classification at the ImageNet 2013 competition. Clarifai’s powerful image and video recognition technology is built on the most advanced machine learning systems and made easily accessible by a clean API, empowering developers all over the world to build a new generation of intelligent applications. One of the most powerful uses of Clarifai’s astonishing technologies is Forevery released on iOS in December 2015.

Matt will walk you through his PhD research and results about image recognition through deep learning/neural networks.


About the Speaker

Matthew received a PhD from NYU in machine learning and image recognition with the pioneers of deep learning and convolutional neural networks. His research produced the top 5 results in the 2013 ImageNet classification competition.  


Matt’s Twitter:  @mattzeiler

results.description:
Come meet Dean Hachamovitch, the man who killed Clippy.

Dean Hachamovitch is one of the most influential human beings who ever served time in the software industry. He served as Corporate Vice President of Internet Explorer at Microsoft—and oversaw the launch of IE9. Under Dean's management, Microsoft helped millions of people experience a secure, private, responsive, cross-platform, and standards-based Web.

That responsibility was earned: Before IE, starting in 1990, Dean led the development of several versions of Word and Office on both Windows and Mac. AutoCorrect? Dean. Automated formatting? Dean. Clippy? NOT Dean. His team was the one that killed Clippy in 2007. RIP. 

Dean is a modest person and does not enjoy being promoted, but the truth is he's had as much of an impact on culture and software as nearly anyone alive. He has graciously agreed to speak about his work at Microsoft, building software at a huge, global scale before anyone knew what that meant—and, if we are very lucky, he might do his Ballmer impersonation.
results.name: Postlight Session: Come meet Dean Hachamovitch, the man who killed Clippy

results.description:
Project Oxford is a set of Machine Learning APIs that help manipulate and retrieve insight from three different kinds of data: vision, speech, and language.  These APIs do things such as Face and Voice Detection, guessing your emotion,  Speech to Text and Text to Speech, and Natural Language Processing, just to name a few.  Websites such as www.how-old.net and https://www.mymoustache.net/ are built on these APIS and are attracting and entertaining tons of users!

Come join this session to walk through setting up the use of these APIs in the new Azure Portal.  We will discuss what the different capabilities of the APIs are, then take a look at a couple of hands on examples!

Speaker

James Quick - Technical Evangelist, Microsoft

James Quick is an avid technologist who specializes in Mobile, 2D Game Development, and Cloud . James studied Computer Science and Spanish at Vanderbilt University where he found his love for mobile through creating his very first application, a Harry Potter Trivia Game .  Upon graduation, he joined Microsoft as the Technical Evangelist in South Florida and has since continued on to New York City.  

During his time at Microsoft, he has been an active member of the tech community working with  various community groups, organizations, and schools.  James found a particular interest in EDU through the Miami Dade STEM Board, leading professional development training for high school teachers and college professor, and being in numerous classrooms throughout South Florida.  James has led workshops and given talks on a regular basis at various meetup and community groups.  James has also spoken at several events such as Code Camps (Boston, NYC, South Florida), ITPalooza, NYC Camp, and more.  James also has a very active online presence through his blog, Github, twitter, etc.

James currently specializing in Mobile Application Development (Android, IOS, and Windows), 2D Game Development, and Cloud.

Pizza will be provided courtesy of Xamarin

results.name: Explore the Power of Project Oxford

results.description:
Jonathan Blessing is the Founder and CEO of Series Digital. In this engaging talk he will talk about his career in software development. In Jonathan's words:

In 1998, not too long after the Internet got pictures, I graduated college and to the practical necessity of rent paying. Because my majors were Comparative Religion and English, I was aggressively unprepared for winning employment.

I surrendered myself to dialing-for-dollars at a Boston-based Internet startup. Good fortune saw that I was seated near the office of the company’s principal software engineer, with whom I shared a puerile sense of humor. He introduced me to software development, recommended books, and soon helped me secure an entry-level position programming
databases. It was 1999, the Internet was blowing up, and if you could spell SQL, there was work.

Today, I run a full-stack software consultancy, where we build great things for awesome clients. Before building my own company, I helped dozens of firms with their software, including some government agencies. It’s been a blast, and I’d like to share what I’ve learned, warts and all with both the aspiring and experienced.
results.name: Reflections on a Career in Software: Pausing at the Midpoint

results.description:
**IMPORTANT: Please register at the General Assembly website and RSVP here to secure your space.**

We’re pleased to announce our first event of 2016: an interactive talk/mixer all about the who, what & why of information design. Information design is a loaded subject that means different things to different people, and takes many different forms. How do we make sense of it all? Is it possible to define information design in today's rapidly changing environment? What does it mean to you? We’ll set the stage with a talk surveying the landscape of information design — the people, roles, activities, and motivations — from the past to the present, followed by a fun networking activity sure to generate some lively discussion.

AGENDA

6:30-7:00pm: Check-in and Networking Activity: “What is Information Design?”

Think while you mingle over light refreshments with a series of interactive posters that probe your knowledge of information design.

7:00-7:30pm: Presentation and Q&A

Get a bird’s-eye view of the field of information design from Michael Babwahsingh and Sheila Pontis, partners at Sense Information Design, and pick up some key discussion points for networking to follow.

7:30-8:30pm: Networking Activity: “Who, What & Why"

Quiz your fellow event-mates on information design-themed questions, share your views, and learn a bit about information design history in this rotating networking activity.

ABOUT OUR EVENT PARTNER

General Assembly is creating a global community of individuals empowered to pursue work they love, by offering full-time immersive programs, long-form courses, and classes and workshops on the most relevant skills of the 21st century – from web development and user experience design, to business fundamentals, to data science, to product management and digital marketing. Established in early 2011 as an innovative community in New York City for entrepreneurs and startup companies, General Assembly is an educational institution that transforms thinkers into creators through education in technology, business and design at fifteen campuses across four continents.

**ONCE AGAIN: Please register at the General Assembly website and RSVP here to secure your space.**
results.name: Information Design: Who, What & Why

results.description:
NOTE: Please include both your first and last name in your meetup profile so you can enter the building.



6:30pm - Networking and Food/Drinks
7:00pm - Featured Presentations

Curtis Larson & Adrian Lanning — Secure, Scalable Uploading to S3 with Slingshot

Slingshot is a great package that helps Meteor clients upload directly to S3 without having to send the data through your Meteor server. In this talk we'll walk you through everything you need to set it up, including the somewhat arcane AWS config you'll need to get it working in a production environment.

Curtis Larson is a NYC-based freelance full stack developer with extensive experience in MeteorJS. He's available for hire at www.curtismlarson.com. You can read more about this topic and other Meteor-related adventures at his blog.

Adrian Lanning is co-founder of Share911, maintains the Roles authorization package and helps run the Meteor-NY meetup.


Alain Goldman – Getting Past Go: Tips & Tricks for the Meteor Beginners after the Todo App


Meteor is a terrific platform for building simple applications quickly without much experience. However, after the tutorials, some users stumble trying to build their own applications, often confused by how things work. Alain Goldman, an organizer of the Beginner Programmers meetup, discusses some of these challenges and suggests how to overcome them.

Alain Goldman is a Rails instructor for beginnerprogrammers.nyc, a Meteor enthusiast, and an organizer for the Beginner Programmers meetup that helps novices learn more about programming languages used in software development careers.

8:00pm - Break
8:15pm - Lightning Talks

Gregory Schwedock – Automatic Server-Side Astronomer Analytics with SpaceMonkey


Don't you hate when ad blockers sabotage your client-side code, dumping your user data into a black hole? When it happened with Astronomer, Greg Schwedock built SpaceMonkey, a package to keep the data safe from the blockers' pull.

Gregory Schwedock is CTO and Cofounder of iChampSports, and activist at The Climate Mobilization. You can follow him on Twitter or find him at Github with handle @shwaydogg, or email him at [masked].


Anders Ramsay – Deploying a Meteor App to Galaxy

"With the free hosting option going away for Meteor, you'll need to find other deployment options for your Meteor apps. Here, we'll walk through a step-by-step process for deploying a Meteor app to the Galaxy platform. We'll discuss common pitfalls and questions, and discuss Meteor app deployment in general."


Anders Ramsay speaks about and teaches Meteor frequently. Follow him on Twitter at @codechron or @andersramsay.

8:45pm - Announcements

9:00pm - Broome Street Bar

We'll head out afterwards to the

Broome Street Bar

at 363 W Broadway, New York, NY 10013 (between Grand & Leonard Streets).

Got an idea for a featured presentation or lightning talk? Please leave us a quick post on our Speaker Form. We're looking for tutorials, walkthroughs, talks, discussion topics, and production apps about or related to Meteor.
results.name: Meteor DevShop

We will run rain or shine, hot or cold. If you RSVP "Yes", please do your best to be on time as we'll only wait a few minutes past 6:30 PM to get rolling. If you have questions, comments, or doubts, feel free to email me.  Looking forward to seeing you.

results.description:
This week I am going to see The Brothers Grimsby I will arrive at 6:45 for the 7:15 pm showing. I  have seat D6 If you are coming post your seat #  If anyone wants to grab a snack before or after the movie and wants to organize that feel free to post and I will join you if I can. 


Hope to see YOU at the movies!   Love, Cassie


Ok who LOVES the movies as much as me? Who has a limited entertainment budget like me? LOL Well this is the event for YOU!

My local theater has discount Tuesday every week and if you sign up online they will even send you a coupon for the concession stand, each week a different one (this weeks is free small popcorn with a drink purchase). They also have those awesome new reclining seats! And you get to choose and pay for your seat in advance so there is no rushing in at the last minute and sitting in the front row and straining your neck!  Here is the link to the theater for more details: http://www.cinemark.com/theatre-detail.aspx?node_id=83854

If you purchase tickets online and can’t make it to the theater, just respond to the email address you receive the confirmation email from ([masked]) and they can refund the payment remotely.

So here is how it's going to work each week. I will choose a movie when the new schedule goes out (Fri/Sat) and choose the movie and showtime. I will buy my seat online and post what row and number. Those of you who wish to join me can buy your seat near me. There are two ways to buy seats: 1) online in advance is your best bet but there is a $1.25 service fee per ticket unless you buy a gift card at the theater and pre-load it 2) At the theater no service fee but you really need to drive there in advance if you want seats near us. OR you can just show up that night and sit wherever there is space available.

Hope to see YOU at the movies!!    Love, Cassie

PS: I am doing this with my friendship group too so if you are S&L do wear your wristbands. These are loads of fun at the movies they glow in the dark!

if you can't make it, no need to post why. We understand and will catch you next time!
results.how_to_find_us: assinged seats
results.name: $5.50 Movie Night- The Brothers Grimsby

results.description:
The Unwanted Houseguest
A Magrevian campaign for 3rd level characters.

The snows have settled heavy in the north of Magrevia, sweeping down from the Buchen Mountains, and blanketing the open hills and treetops with a deadly field of white. The cold eats at the fingers of men tending their animals in barns, and searching for firewood stockpiled against the winter. It came early this year, and Mother help us all.

The hall sits alone in a clearing, trees approach on all sides but a high stone wall holds them back, cutting a walled garden from the wilds. At shuttered windows a glow speaks of warmth and shelter. From one, the sounds of merriment can even be heard, but there is a tension to that laughter, a strain in the cheer… are the participants forcing this celebration to keep the cold at bay, or is it the cold itself doing the forcing?

The province of Magrevia is a land of dark shadows and deep forests. A century before, the Empire of Thyatis sent its troops, intent on adding the region to its dominion. Today, the Thyatians stay within their outposts, still unable to penetrate the wild lands that surround them. The Magrevian people continue to dwell in the communities that have sheltered them for generations, their doors and windows closed tight each night against the darkness. The Unwanted Houseguest is a storyline for 5th edition Dungeons and Dragons, for characters of 2-4th level. The focus is on solving mysteries, and the challenge of surviving the horror surrounding you.
results.name: D&D 5E: The Unwanted Houseguest - Session 3

Aside from our League play we offer Open Play 6 days a week. 1 hour and 45 minute sessions only $11 midweek.

Format: 3 teams of 5 per court. Score by 1’s. Games to 7. Winner stays but must sit after 2 games. No refs. Call your own. Our moderator will help things along. All players must bring a white and a dark shirt (not grey). This is a friendly run. Anyone with the wrong attitude will not be allowed back. Age: 21+

Our open runs are designed for good fun and a run. The A / B breakdown is purely a self rating device to try and split things up in an enjoyable manner. Think of it as if you were going to the park to play. If you are average or above go to the A court. If you are average or below go to B.  It is not exact. There is always going to be some crossover.  

***Please note- RSVP'g on Meetup will not reserve your spot. Please go to our website to sign up.*** A credit card payment is required to reserve your space. Just click the session that interests you.


http://nyurban.com/open-play-basketball/

We will send you a confirmation email. Show up at the Gym with I.D. We will have you on our list but please bring your receipt. No payment at the door.

 We're starting a new chapter in the story, so now would be an excellent time for  any new players to join. No experience with SOTC or FATE is required. We have a few pregen characters ready to use.


The campaign is a pulp adventure based on the old lost world romances of authors like H. Rider Haggard, Arthur Conan Doyle, and Edgar Rice Burroughs.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lost_World_(genre)

This is a rules light FATE-based game based on the pulp hero novels of the 20/30's.

Below is a link to a SRD for Spirit Of the Century if you'd like to get a sense of the rules.

http://www.faterpg.com/dl/sotc-srd.html

I'll be keeping a campaign log for any current or future players in the Specific Game Discussions section of the message board. http://www.meetup.com/Manhattan-Gamers-Guild/messages/boards/thread/49513980

We'll be taking over the space at 7:00 sharp, and the evening should be in full swing by 7:10!  (Latecomers are still welcome, of course.)

Writers, if you're bringing something to present, don't forget to bring ample COMPLETE and IDENTICAL copies of the scene(s) --- one copy for each actor you'll need, plus one copy for a reader of any stage directions.  (And if you're able to provide character descriptions in the form of a breakdown appended as page 1 --- that's never a bad idea. :))

Actors, come ready to read!

results.description:
Want to get off hourly billing?  Is your income tied to the current project you are working on? Is your work completely custom for each and every client?  If the answer to all these are “yes” then I can show you how you can pivot your current project based business model.

Follow along as I explain how I managed to pivot my WP development business from being an hourly/project based developer with a plate full of different clients and projects to one with exclusive clients who all go through the same funnel and process month over month.

PRESENTED BY: JASON RESNICK

OPENING PRESENTATION: Content First WordPress Development

When building a WordPress website you may pick a theme and then try to make your images & copy fit. If your images and copy don’t match exactly your results may frustrate you, your client, and your audience.

By taking a content first approach you save time, money, and frustrations. Content first is about gather & organizing your content and then building a WordPress site around it. You will see a complete build up from research to prototype to design and finally launch.

PRESENTED BY:VICTOR RAMIREZ

GET ONE-ON-ONE ASSISTANCE AT OUR HELP DESK:  

The team from LoudFeed will be available throughout the evening to help you with your WordPress issues and answer your questions.

ABOUT THE PRESENTERS:

Jason Resnick, Your Partner In Code. Founder of rezzz.com and a developer who helps small businesses increase their conversions on their WordPress websites whether it’s for ecommerce, list building or downloads.

Victor Ramirez began his foray into the interwebs building websites and email newsletters for various art projects. He now owns An Abstract Agency in NYC where he works on & teaches digital marketing. In his free time he mentors WordPress  at Thinkful and is the lead singer of a Misfits cover band.
results.name: How To Productize Your WordPress Service

results.description:
In the work session we’ll learn about the elements, or patterns, that make up the system of (front-end) web design and development. This collaborative work session is organized as a 45-60 minute talk and 1 hour of workshopping. We’ll focus on some of the higher-level patterns that can help you be a more effective front-end developer. The latter part of the workshop we will help everyone get up and running with these new tools. Everyone can participate as you may already be using some of these patterns in your daily practice! 


Higher level patterns we’ll aim to cover:


• [Pattern] Command Line Interface

• <a>[Pattern] Directory Structure</a>

• Folder structure/layout

• <a>[Pattern] HTML Templating</a><a>[Pattern] </a>

• <a>Shareable Data</a><a>[Pattern] </a>

• <a>Build Tools</a><a>[Pattern] Text Editor</a>

This workshop is the hands on companion to Claudina Sarahe’s Pattern Language for Web Development.

If you have questions that need answers? Please bring them along, there will be one hour of time and folks to help. 

Big thanks to our host :
results.name: SassShop: Patterns for Effective Frontend Development

results.description:
Gene Murrow will call a lovely program of English country dance with live musical accompaniment by Cynthia Shaw, Paul Friedman, John Austin!

The third Playford Ball prep session will also be featured in the dance selection tonight.

Come dance to a live caller and band with Country Dance New York.  We are an intergenerational, multiethnic, smoke and alcohol free, inclusive community with one thing in common:  we love to contra and English country dance!

English country dance is choreographed community dancing, with repertoire ranging from court dances of the 1650s through dances composed this year. If you’ve seen any of the Jane Austen movies, you’ve glimpsed some kinds of ECD.

Please bring a pair of clean, soft soled shoes {no spike heels} to dance in, and a water bottle.  We ask that you not use strongly scented grooming products as the smell can become overwhelming on the dance floor when things start to heat up.

Country Dance New York has been hosting contra dances most Saturdays, and English country dancing most Tuesdays, at Church of the Village for almost 70 years.   COV is located at 201 W. 13 St., on the northwest corner of 7th Avenue.

Beginners' session on Saturdays {for contra} is from 7:30 to 8:00.  Dancing for all from 8:00 until 10:45.  Hang out with us at a local diner after the dance.

Beginner's session on Tuesdays {for ECD} is from 7:00 to 7:30.  Dancing for all from 7:30 to 10:30.

Cost:  $15 for general public; $12 members and for full time students with ID.  Be sure to tell the people at the door if this is your first time dancing with us.  They will give you a free pass to return as our guest!

To see what contra dancing looks like, click here:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mM5vNzFxxBs

To see what English country dancing looks like, click here:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rB40AvJnMUY

Join us on Facebook:  https://www.facebook.com/groups/2449906414/

For a complete schedule of our upcoming season, and for more information, visit our website.

See you on the dance floor!
results.how_to_find_us: Take the ACE, 1,2,3, L or F train to 14th St. We are on the northwest corner of 13th Street and 7th Avenue. Street address is 201 W. 13th.

results.description:
Our Tuesday night Central Park training workouts are typically tempo runs or hill repeats.  These workouts are usually very well attended with a wide variety of paces.

The meeting spot is at the 72nd street transverse by Bethesda Fountain. There we'll give the full workout details, including distance, pacing groups, expected run time, and where we plan on meeting at the end. You can expect a typical workout to be between 5 and 8 miles (or less during hill workouts).

A note on warm ups: We do not do a full warm up as a group in Central Park, so we encourage you to show up at 7 p.m. having jogged an easy mile or two ahead of time.

If it's your first time meeting us, feel free to come a few minutes early with any questions.  There are many other groups who meet on 72nd St so look for the one with folks in Whippet singlets.

Please note that there is no place to store bags inside Central Park. Pack light, or store your bags at a nearby gym if you are a member. Another option is the New York Running Company at the Time Warner Center, which stays open until 9pm: http://www.therunningcompany.net/new-yorks-homepage
results.how_to_find_us: We meet on 72nd transverse at the point that overlooks Bethesda Fountain
results.name: Central Park Training Run

results.description:
The format of course stays the same: 5 minutes to show off your hack, and 5 minutes for the audience to applaud, cry, laugh, inquiry, snore, chew, stand, sit, dance, grow, interact, etc. But, of course, we hope that the audience provides lots of great feedback and asks interesting questions (probably while sitting, though dancing audience members are certainly free to participate as well)!


Show us what you've got! But, remember, no startup pitches, no work related projects[0], and no deckware! See you at Meetup!

If you're interested in presenting, this is the url to use:

•  http://j.mp/PresentHackAtRound37


NOTE: All money raised from the $5 RSVP fee will be donated to an hacker-focused organization in need. (Last time we donated it to the Software Freedom Conservancy! https://sfconservancy.org/)

[0]: Let us clarify the "no job projects" rule. We want to promote the projects that people do in their spare time, for fun, or utility, and not the kinds of projects that are only applicable to people who work in your company, or your direct clients. On the other hand, there may be a project that you've built primarily at work, that solves a *general* problem that your company has allowed you to release with a libre license-- this is usually fine.


Questions We Expect To Be Asked

Do I need to RSVP if I sign up to present?

* Yes! We sometimes need to use the RSVP's as a name list to comply with building security. If you are selected to present but do not have an RSVP, contact [masked] and we'll sort it out for you.

Do I have to pay if I sign up to present?

* No! Anyone who even so much as submits a presentation proposal, whether or not you're actually selected, will *not* be charged. If you want to present, you already have "skin in the game." We're trying to make everyone who wants to attend invested enough to *actually* show up.

I have a fixed income / am a student / just simply don't have $5 to spare, can I still come?

* Please contact [masked], let us know, and we'll take care of you! We definitely want to be as inclusive as possible, and if money is your only problem we won't let it get in the way of you joining us!

results.description:
We are extremely honored to have Dan Friedman join us on Tuesday, March 15th for an evening of "Ask me anything".

Dan is a leading authority in the Scheme community and a prominent author in the field of programming languages.

About Dan Friedman 

Dr. Daniel Paul Friedman is a professor of Computer Science at Indiana University in Bloomington, Indiana. His research focuses on programming languages, and he is a prominent author in the field.

With David Wise, Friedman wrote a highly influential paper on lazy programming, specifically on lazy streams (ICALP 1976). The paper, entitled "Cons should not evaluate its arguments," is one of the first publications pushing for the exploration of a programming style with potentially infinite data structures and a form of programming that employs no computational effects (though programs may diverge). Over the 1970s, Friedman and Wise explored the topic in depth and also considered extensions to the world of parallel computing.

In the 1980s, Friedman turned to the study of Scheme. He explored the use of macros for defining programming languages; with Kohlbecker, Felleisen, and Duba, he co-introduced the notion of 'hygienic macros' in a 1986 LFP paper that is still widely cited today.

With Haynes and Wand, he simultaneously studied the nature of continuation objects, their uses, and the possibilities of constraining them. Following that, Friedman and Felleisen introduced a lambda calculus with continuations and control operators. Their work has spawned work on semantics, connections between classical logic and computation, and practical extensions of continuations.

Friedman is also a prolific text book author. His first text book, The Little LISPer, dates back to 1974 and is still in print in its fourth edition, now called The Little Schemer (with Felleisen). Friedman and Felleisen wrote three more "little" books in the 1990s: The Little MLer, The Seasoned Schemer, and A Little Java, A Few Patterns.

Friedman is also the lead author of Essentials of Programming Languages, a text book on programming languages. As such, it changed the landscape of language text books in the 1980s, shifting the focus from surveys of languages to the study of principles via series of interpreters. Today's text books on this topic tend to follow this organization, employing operational semantics and type theory instead of interpreters. Like The Little LISPer, Essentials of Programming Languages is a long-living book and is in its third edition now.

Friedman also resumed work on his "Little" series with The Reasoned Schemer (with Byrd and Kiselyov), explaining logic programming via an extension of Scheme. 

Most recently Daniel Friedman and Carl Eastlund  published The Little Prover which introduces inductive proofs as a way to determine facts about computer programs.

It is written in an approachable, engaging style of question-and-answer, with the characteristic humor of The Little Schemer (fourth edition, MIT Press). Sometimes the best way to learn something is to sit down and do it; the book takes readers through step-by-step examples showing how to write inductive proofs. The Little Prover assumes only knowledge of recursive programs and lists (as presented in the first three chapters of The Little Schemer) and uses only a few terms beyond what novice programmers already know. The book comes with a simple proof assistant to help readers work through the book and complete solutions to every example.
.
results.name: An Evening with Dan Friedman

Futsal Pick up games (intermediate to advanced level)

Fee: $10 dollars per player per game; pay through paypal.

Only 10 players per game, no subs. One game is 55-60 minutes. Be early. Every player rotates as a Goalie for 6 minutes, time it with an electronic scoreboard. We play without a break. Regulation size goals with nets. Futsal ball. Please make sure to bring a white and a red t-shirt, indoor shoes. Games are competitive, but friendly. Please keep in mind that these games are definitely not for the beginners. 

No fouls, zero tolerance to this. “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game”. Minimum physical contact means fewer injuries and no violence. No charging, no displacing with your arms or body to gain the position on the ball. No running into the opponent. Play the ball, not the player. Time it, don’t foul it. 

Refunds: Cancel your RSVP 24 hours or more before the game and we will make the refund. No refund for late cancelations; no exceptions. 

Name of the school William J. O’Shea (100W): The school entrance is located on West 77th street between Columbus and Amsterdam avenues (pretty much in the middle of the block) on the south side of the street. You'll see a row of 5-6 metal doors. Open the door or ring the buzzer (on your right), Please wait and someone will open the door for you.  the court is on the second floor. 

For questions: Use the MEETUP message and notifications tools. 

Post pictures and videos at:

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Futsalacrossamerica?ref=hl

Twitter: https://twitter.com/FutsalAcrossA

Thank you for being part of Futsal Across America.

Enjoy the game!

Bring a project and get to work, use our tools, drink a homebrew beer, hang out, and draw on advice from our wonderful community. Visitors are strongly encouraged to bring a project to work on, or at least a laptop.

Find out more about Hack Manhattan at our website, hackmanhattan.com. Not everyone can come in every Tuesday, so most of the community happens on our mailing list.

results.description:
How often do we take the time to really focus on releasing all the tension and stress that we accumulate in our body?

Not very.

Instead, we just keep on trucking, hoping it all will magically disappear.

But we know that won't be the case unless we do something about it.

Enter Osho's powerful Kundalini meditation, a kind of active meditation specifically designed for modern life that helps us to release stress and unblock our energy.

Comprised of 15 minutes of shaking, 15 minutes of dancing, 15 minutes of stillness (sitting or standing), and 15 minutes of silence (shavasana), this meditation is a really amazing way to shake everything off, get past self-doubts and limiting beliefs.

Because it's both invigorating and relaxing, it gets us out of our mind and reminds us of how incredibly good being an embodied being can feel like when we get out of our way. 

This practice creates a release of pent up emotions, tension and blockages in the body, and it's energizing, uplifting and calming at the same time. It's often a really amazing way to make room for inspiration because once those doubts are removed, creativity flows like whoa!


Join us every other Tuesday as we shake it all off, and leave it on the floor.


Shake It All Off! Active Meditation for Tension Release and Well-Being

Every other Tuesday, 7-8:30 pm

Location TBA (Manhattan)

$15 donation / $20 for 2 if you bring a friend

Register


NOTE: in order to cover costs, this event requires at least 5 people to be signed up per date 24 hrs prior for it to happen. Please RSVP mindfully so I know what size room to book for us in advance.



---------------------------------------------------------------------------------


"After attending Melody’s “Shake It Off” and “Embodiment” workshops, not only was my personal way of relating to my physical, mental, and spiritual enhanced, but it motivated me to seek out entire aspects of the human condition that have supported my growth as a social worker deeply. Prior to working with Melody, I had been enamored with the mind and aspects of intelligence that caused me to completely disconnect from my body; I did not take care of it, and it did not take care of me. I feel so fortunate to have experientially learned with Melody’s guidance, that the body holds many of the keys to inner peace, whether for my self or my clients."

Abbi K., New York, NY


---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

MELODY KIERSZ

Melody Kiersz wants you to stop trying to prove yourself worthy and start living the life that makes you happy.

Melody holds a degree in Happiness from the prestigious New York University, is a Certified Holistic Health Counselor graduated from the Institute for Integrative Nutrition, a member of the American Association of Drugless Practitioners, and a Certified Yoga Teacher through Jungle Yoga Ashram.

Melody is a deep listener and reads between the lines to guide you in discovering the ways you're holding yourself back from your true expression. She specializes in healing our relationship with our bodies, our selves and others, improving body image and self-esteem, increasing our ability to speak up, share, and allow ourselves to be seen and loved as we are. As the Founder of Naked Wellness, her goal is to guide you as you peel all those layers of resistance so you can turn yourself on for a life full of health, passion, power, freedom, joy and pleasure.

Based in New York City, Melody offers in-person and long-distance private sessions, and is really passionate about everyone really getting that they are absolutely perfect exactly as they are.

She can be reached at <a>[masked]</a>.
results.name: Shake it all off! Active Meditation for Tension Release and Well-Being

results.description:
Welcome to Week 3 of the Urban Farming challenge!

In Week 1, we had an open brainstorm surrounding the problems, technology, and potential solutions in the urban agriculture industry.

In Week 2, we discussed the proposed solutions from Week 1 in a little more detail. David Marini, founder of Art of Aquaponics, joined us to add creativity and insight into specific questions. We aimed the discussion at 

• Tackling the general public's sentiment toward urban farming


• Possibilities between food sharing apps (whether on financial or barter systems)


• Taking advantage of the inefficiency of wasted space in urban spaces not fit for human occupation (basements, attics, crawlspaces, etc)


• Exploring the possibilities behind introducing a wider variety of high-nutrient seeds and plants into the urban produce ecosystem

• Building a financial case for urban farming

At this week's meetup, we're going to host Andrew Carter of Blue Planet Consulting, an agency dedicated to integrating agriculture back into cities.

We'll aim the discussion at finding the top-priority projects to pursue immediately, which Andrew can help add insight to, given his depth of involvement in urban farming projects.

Make sure you bring your thinking caps! This is where the conversations get specific and actionable.

See you soon!

-Dan & the Think Tank Team (Mike, Mikayla, Kevin, and Brendan)
results.how_to_find_us: Take the elevator to the 8th floor. Turn down the hall to the right, and Room 806 will be on your right.
results.name: Urban Farming Challenge (Week 3/4): Building NYC Solutions w/ Andrew Carter

results.description:
A Course in Miracles Healing Clinic at CRS
 Mon. & Tue. 7 – 7:40 pm
Sun 1 – 2 pm (12 – 1 pm on 2nd Sun of the month)
Suggested donation $20. No one is turned away.

Bring any issue you are facing right now — physically, emotionally, mentally, and/or spiritually. With eyes closed (you will be seated and a healer will stand nearby; no touching is involved), a CRS healer, trained in A Course in Miracles and spiritual reading/healing, will observe you with his inner sight, free of any judgments, as your truly are, a perfect shining spirit. Together, will ask the Holy Spirit (or Inner Guide if you prefer) to bring us directly to whatever seed thought is causing your current issues and ask for guidance about how your spirit really wants to make use of your present situation for its growth and sharing of love. After about 10 minutes of meditation, we will share the inspirational guidance that we receive. 

Aside from sharing the message that we receive from the Holy Spirit, we don't talk during this meetup event. We share healing quietly and provide you with an opportunity to come to rest, reflect, and remember who you truly are, in a supportive, non-judgmental, meditative environment.

We'd like to offer you an opportunity to experience stillness of mind and peace so that you can return to harmony with your true nature and purpose. Then you will find that rather than needing "solutions" to "problems" you will realize that you have no problems except those that you project.

We call this spiritual healing but it is not religious nor connected with any church or group. It is simply a practice of meditating together on our true nature and connecting with universal spirit/energy or what you will.

A Note About the Role of Words in Healing: "Strictly speaking, words play no part at all in healing. The motivating factor is prayer, or asking. What you ask for you receive. But this refers to the prayer of the heart, not to the words you use in praying. Sometimes the words and the prayer are contradictory; sometimes they agree. It does not matter. God does not understand words, for they were made by separated minds to keep them in the illusion of separation. Words can be helpful, particularly for the beginner, in helping concentration and facilitating the exclusion, or at least the control, of extraneous thoughts. Let us not forget, however, that words are but symbols of symbols. They are thus twice removed from reality...." — A Course in Miracles Manual for Teachers, Section 21

"Since only the mind can be sick, only the mind can be healed. Only the mind is in need of healing." —"PSYCHOTHERAPY: Purpose, Process and Practice,"Supplements to A Course in Miracles
results.how_to_find_us: CRS is located one block east of Broadway and one and a half blocks south of Union Square, above Think Coffee shop.
results.name: Walk-In Spiritual Healing Clinic

results.description:
OPENING NIGHT IS SOLD OUT

so unless you bought tickets online there will be no tickets at the door- 

BUT THERE 4 more days at 4 locations with 142 films and After parties!

I am hosting THURSDAY at PS 69 in Jackson Heights! details to follow


QUEENS WORLD FILM FEST 6... If you feel the Academy Awards EXCLUDED emerging people of color and women filmmakers - see the films and meet the filmmakers who, despite financial and cultural obstacles, created classics that inspire international innovation in story telling today!

1970's BLACK CINEMA PIONEER - creating a genre for future filmmakers

 "Sweet Sweetback's Baadasssss Song" with Melvin Van Peebles 
venue: Museum of the Moving Image 
address:[masked]th Avenue, Astoria, NY 11106 
when: Wed. March 16, 2016  @7pm

This year's "Spirit of Queens" Award goes to independent film director Melvin Van Peebles and we will celebrate him with a screening of his work in the beautiful Redstone Theatre.

 Peebles is an American actor, director, screenwriter, playwright, novelist, painter and composer. Successful in every medium, Van Peebles is most famous for his movie Sweet Sweetback's Baadasssss Song‎, which heralded a new era of African-American cinema. I

On the evening of March 16 at MoMI,  a Q&A with the legendary Mr. Peebles, moderated by MoMI trustee Warrington Hudlin, founder of the Black Filmmaker Foundation.

1980's WOMAN DIRECTOR - capturing a generation

Smithereens with Susan Seidelman 
venue: Museum of the Moving Image 
address:[masked]th Avenue, Astoria, NY 11106 
when: Saturday March 19, 2016 @7pm

To highlight the ‎IndieCollect film preservation campaign, Susan Seidelman's 1982 movie, Smithereens, will be showcased at MoMI on Closing Night, Saturday, March 19. The Smithereensnegative was found by the IndieCollect team in the vaults of DuArt Film & Video after DuArt closed its photo-chemical division, and was placed at the Academy Film Archive for safekeeping.

Smithereens was the first American independent feature to be shown in the Official Competition at the Cannes Film Festival. The international rights toSmithereens were recently acquired by SHOUT! Factory (shoutfactory.com), and the film will be released by The Criterion Collection. Susan Seidelman subsequently directed the hugely successful movie, Desperately Seeking Susan, featuring Madonna in her screen debut and the Sex and the City  TV Pilot.

Event starts at 7:00 and will be followed by a Q & A with Ms. Seidelman and IndieCollects Executive Director Sandra Schulberg. 

Go online and see if there is a block of film that inspires you... there are after parties and opportunities to meet local and international filmmakers too -


 BUY TICKETS and see you at the shows!

results.description:
A coding education is the golden ticket to a great job these days. Employers are crying out for more candidates with the tech skills they need. Everyone from President Obama, to state governors, city mayors and schools are trying to figure out ways to better help students learn these valuable skills. 

In response, lot's of coding bootcamps & platforms have emerged offering short intensive online & in-person courses that aim to teach these skills quickly. 

Join us on March 15th to discuss these different approaches to coding education, and dive into whether new models are better positioned than traditional schools to deliver desired outcomes for students and employers. 

Awesome panelists include:

Dan Friedman, Thiel Fellow, CEO, Thinkful, an online school offering project-based and mentor-led courses designed to help students get the technical skills needed for career advancement. 


Marissa Shorenstein, President, AT&T - New York, member of NYC Tech Talent Pipeline Advisory Board and co-creator of the nanodegree program in partnership with Udacity. 


Liz Eggleston, Co-Founder, Course Report, an information platform and research company that compares coding school options. 


Rebekah Rombom, VP, Business Development at The Flatiron School,  a programming school with independently audited student outcomes including a 99% job placement rate at an average salary of $74k.


Moderator: Sharon Laday, Co-Founder, NYEdTech Meetup

Additional Panelist announcement coming soon! 

Here's to another great NYEdTech Meetup! In the meantime, connect with fellow NYEdTech'ers online at: 

• Facebook - http://ow.ly/h4CZc

• Twitter - @NYEdTech

• Hashtag - #NYEdTech

And of course, we would like to thank our gracious sponsors! 

The world's largest learning company now has a developer platform! Build your own applications using Pearson's exciting content. Learn more at http://developer.pearson.com

Knewton personalizes digital courses for students so every student is engaged and no student slips through the cracks.
results.name: Coding Bootcamps & the Employment Promise

results.description:
When Japan adopted Valentine's Day they did something curious. They made the day's color "red" and they made it a day for women to give chocolate to men. Well, in an effort to balance the scales, they created "White Day" (wai-tto de-i) on March 14th (one month after Valentine's Day) to make up for it. On White Day men give chocolates to women. So guys, come out to our special edition White Day (a day late to keep it on a Tuesday) and bring chocolate. Ladies, come on our and get some free chocolate! Oh, and there will be shochu, of course.

Have you tried shochu? The traditional distilled spirit from Japan? It's more dry than sake and much easier to drink than other spirits. Goes great when paired with food.

Stephen Lyman, editor of http://kampai.us and shochu sommelier for SakaMai and other NYC Japanese restaurants, pours selected shochu each Tuesday around NYC. The location will be on the move so stay on top of each week here on meetup or by following Stephen on twitter @kampaius
results.name: White Day Shochu'sday @ Uminoie

You'll have the opportunity to learn and use new tools to participate in circles by sharing yourself, understanding others, and growing in both enjoyment of and capacity for presence and deep connection.

results.description:
Open Office Hours

Meeting every Tuesday evening, 7:00PM - 10:00PM

This month's host: Chartbeat


Office hours is open to developers of any background and skill level. Newcomers to programming, Python, or NYC are all welcome, as well as experienced programmers and locals. The purpose of this event is to promote learning and community involvement within the NYC Python community.

Activities vary and may include (but are not limited to):

Informal tech talks: Topics can be anything related to Python or programming. Have a topic you'd like to see presented? Leave a comment starting with "Talk topic suggestion". Want to present? Message the organizers.

Technical discussions: Bring your code and / or questions about any relevant topic, and there will most likely be someone present who can help. For questions about a specific topic, please leave a comment in the form of "Need help with Django / Nginx / SQL". If you're able to help with a particular topic, please leave a comment in the form of "Can help with Flask / Apache / NoSQL".

Note: Recruiting and other solicitation are not allowed at these events. These are run for developers by developers. Behavior that makes others uncomfortable will not be tolerated, and offenders will be asked to leave.

Profuse thanks go to our sponsors for loaning us this space and providing refreshments.

Thank you, and see you Tuesday night!
results.name: Tuesday Office Hours
